thread.title: Women artists get their due in Irvine
thread.title_full: Women artists get their due in Irvine

author: ANTONIE BOESSENKOOL
title: Women artists get their due in Irvine
text: Women artists get their due in Irvine Oct. 3, 2015 Updated 12:00 a.m. 1 of 6 The large-scale mural, circa 1953, that Art Deco painter Jessie Arms Botke created for the Oaks Hotel in Ojai will be a highlight of “Independent Visions: Women Artists of California, 1880-1940” at the Irvine Musem. IMAGE COURTESY IRVINE MUSEUM 1 of 6 Detail from the circa-1953 mural that art deco specialist Jessie Arms Botke created for the Oaks Hotel in Ojai. IRVINE MUSEUM 1 of 6 Anna Hills’ 1915 work, “Spring in Laguna,” will be part of the “Independent Visions: Women Artists of California, 1880-1940” at the Irvine Museum. IRVINE MUSEUM 1 of 6 Artist Donna Schuster changed her painting style over the course of her career, encompassing both Impressionism, like this “Girl in a Hammock,” and Expressionism. PHOTOS COURTESY IRVINE MUSEUM 1 of 6 “Los Angeles Harbor” is one of the works by Donna Schuster that will be part of the “Independent Visions: Women Artists of California, 1880-1940” exhibit at the Irvine Museum. IRVINE MUSEUM 1 of 6 Euphemia Charlton Fortune’s “Study of Monterey Bay” is displayed in the California women artists exhibit. IRVINE MUSEUM
